A cloud built. controlled. and maintained by a single entity.

• Complete control over resources and security.
  • Data is not colocated with other organisations data

• Upfront CapEx cost: hardware must be purchased for startup and maintenance.
  • Lacks the benefits of public cloud.

Is built. controlled. and maintained by a third-party cloud provider. Anyone that wants to purchase cloud services can access and use resources. This availability is a key difference between other cloud models.

• No capital expenditures to scale up.
  • Applications can be quickly provisioned and deprovisioned.
  • Organizations pay only for what they use.
• Organizations don't have complete control over resources and security.
Uses both public and private cloud in an inter-connected environment.

• Can be used to allow a private cloud to surge for increase. temporary demand by deploying public cloud resources.
  • Can be used to provide an extra layer of security.
    For example. users can flexibly choose which services to keep in public cloud and which to deploy to their private cloud infrastructure.

• Provides the most flexibility.
  • Organisations can determine where to run their applications.
  • .
• Complexity of Management & Implementation
Uses features from many cloud providers. you deal with two (or more) public cloud providers and manage resources and security in both environments.
Typically a one-time. up-front expenditure to purchase or secure tangible resources.
Typically spending money on services or products over time.

Prompt: What are the two types of expenses to consider when comparing IT infrastructure models?
Answer: Capital Expenditure and Operational Expenditure

• No upfront costs.
  • No need to purchase and manage costly infrastructure that users might not use to its fullest potential.
  • The ability to pay for more resources when they're needed.
  • The ability to stop paying for resources that are no longer needed.
